results.title: Festival of family classics. -Volume 2.
results.brief_description: Features 2 family classics; “Around the world in 80 days” Part 1 & 2; Phineas Fogg, accompanied by his loyal valet, Passpartout, embark on a wager to circle the world in 80 days. Their ability to meet the deadline is threatened by Detective Fix who mistakes Fogg for a bank robber. “Puss in boots”; Orlando the cat learns to talk thanks to a pair of magic boots. Will he use his new power for good? Introduced by Chelsea Brown.

results.title: Festival of family classics.- Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Introduced by Chelsea Brown this tape includes 3 stories. “Cinderella”; the classic story with the inclusion of a bumbling knight and an absentminded godmother makes this story an hilariously funny one; “A Christmas tree”; based on the Charles Dickens story this tale is about Peter and Mary, two children out to recover the spirit of Christmas; “Robin Hood”; Robin Hood is captured by the mean sheriff of Nottingham.

results.title: Festival in Edinburgh
results.creator_credit: Douglas Clarke, Howard Thomas and Associated British-Pathe
results.brief_description: Scenes from the 1954 Edinburgh Festival of music and drama, including a short sequence showing Margot Fonteyn and Michael Somes dancing ‘The Firebird’, Ann Todd and Paul Rogers in a scene from Macbeth, Sir Adrian Boult conducting the National Youth Orchestra and before the castle.

results.title: Festival in Adelaide
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, Richard Mason, Loch Townsend, Malcolm Otton, Maslyn Williams, Stanley Hawes and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows something of the preparation that went into the Adelaide Festival of Arts 1962, and excerpts from the performances themselves. General notes: AFI Award: silver award (documentary) 1963.

results.title: Festival express
results.creator_credit: Bob Smeaton, John Trapman, Gavin Poolman, Peachtree Films and Apollo Films
results.brief_description: In the summer of 1970, two Canadian music promoters decided to put on a touring music festival. Instead of the artists meeting at each location, they put everyone on a train that went from city to city. What a ride! This documentary is a re-discovery of the musical journey that took place and for some the great emotional journey from the vibe and friendship/good times that happened on the train. Never before had performers been so well looked after and the train became a place for one hell of party - Buddy Guy says at one point he tried to sleep but was worried he might miss something - one car was for blues jamming, one for folk, one for food and one for, well, other activities. The whole event ran at a great loss, word on the street was that the concerts should be free and youth of the day would charge the gates causing trouble at every town. That is why this footage was not uncovered for more that 30 years, no one had any money at the end of it to produce the film and it just sat in a vault! Some split-screen technique is used combining contemporary interviews with original footage or simply showing the two points-of-view of a two camera shot. Performers featured are: “The Band”, “Delaney and Bonnie”, “The Flying Burrito Brothers”, “Grateful Dead”, “Buddy Guy Blues Band”, “Ian & Sylvia & The Great Speckled Bird”, “Janis Joplin”, “Mashmakhan” and “Sha Na Na”. Cities visited include Toronto, Winnipeg and Calgary (with a stop at a liquor store to re-stock!). Two disc set contains lots of extras.

results.title: Festival Casals 1970: Pablo Casals conducting
results.creator_credit: Ken Sale and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Spanish born cellist Pablo casals is filmed here conducting a rehearsal of Beethoven’s 7th Symphony in preparation for the annual Casals Festival at San Juan, Puerto Rico. The film concentrates on the 94 year old Casals’ gestures and speech as he conducts, and interrupts to correct the playing of the orchestra during the opening to the first movement.

results.title: Festival 78
results.creator_credit: Christopher Wade, Gil Cardinal and Access Alberta
results.brief_description: Festival 78 was the first cultural festival in Commonwealth history, and was held in conjunction with the XI Commonwealth Games in Edmonton, 1978. As an exchange of culture from all countries there was emphasis on national dancing, and many performances of all kinds took place throughout the city of Edmonton. Written and narrated by Dave Billington.

results.title: Festen = Celebration
results.creator_credit: Thomas Vinterberg, Brigitte Hald, Dogme 95 and Nimbus Film Productions
results.brief_description: The first film made by the Dogme 95 Collective. Formed in Denmark in 1995, Dogme is an international group of filmmakers committed to an independent film practice that wishes to see cinema become again an innovative, experimental and politically subversive art. Whatever the controversy the Dogme 95 Manifesto has generated, what is undoubted is the artistic success of “Festen”. Filmed on digital video, in natural light and in natural sound, the simple narrative describes the arrival to a manor house of an extended bourgeois family coming to celebrate the patriarch’s 60th birthday. But his three surviving children come to the celebration with widely ambivalent emotions: one son has arrived to mourn the suicide of his twin, the remaining daughter has to deal with the family’s silent rejection of her black boyfriend, and the eldest brother is locked in a vicious cycle of self-hate, violence and alcoholism. Sitting down together - children, cousins, grandchildren - the patriarch’s youngest son rises and asks his father to choose from two speeches he has prepared. What follows is a weekend of chaos and betrayal where the family is torn apart by secrets long denied. But “Festen” is not only a film about the lies within one family. With brutal precision it juxtaposes the hypocrisy and exploitive relations of the nuclear family with the subjugation and inequalities of contemporary European class society. Exhausting and exhilarating, “Festen” is an examination of a society on the brink of collapse, paradoxically both detached and passionate in its study of the logical excesses of capitalist materialism. There are no special effects in “Festen”, no occult creatures from outer space, but before its resolution the audience has become implicated in a horror that is truly monstrous, has come face to face with an evil that we would like to believe is alien but we recognise as all too familiar. (Awards: Winner of the Special Jury Prize at the 1998 Cannes Festival) Cast includes Ulrich Thomsen, Henning Moritzen, Thomas Bo Larsen, Birthe Neumann, Paprika Steen, Trine Dyrholm and Helle Dolers. In Danish with English subtitles.
